turns.content: It is common for 401(k) plans to offer profit-sharing as a feature. According to a report by the Plan Sponsor Council of America, approximately 55% of 401(k) plans offered profit-sharing in 2020. However, it's worth noting that the specific percentage of plans offering profit-sharing may vary depending on the source of the data and the criteria used to define a "401(k) plan."
what 401k plans do not offer profit sharing?

While it is common for 401(k) plans to offer profit-sharing, not all plans do so. Some smaller employers or businesses may opt not to offer profit-sharing for various reasons, such as cost or complexity. However, it's worth noting that the specific types of 401(k) plans that do not offer profit-sharing may vary depending on the source of the data and the criteria used to define a "401(k) plan."

It's also important to note that while profit-sharing is a common feature in many 401(k) plans, it is not a requirement under the law. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) provides guidelines and rules for how 401(k) plans must be structured, but it is up to the plan sponsor (usually the employer) to determine the specific features of the plan, including whether or not to offer profit-sharing.
what's the smallest company that offers profit sharing

The size of a company that offers profit-sharing can vary greatly depending on the industry, location, and other factors. However, it is possible for even small companies to offer profit-sharing as a benefit to their employees.

For example, a small business with only a few employees may offer a simple profit-sharing plan where a percentage of the company's profits is distributed among the employees at the end of the year. In some cases, small businesses may even partner with a financial services provider to set up a 401(k) plan with profit-sharing features, although this can be more complex and may not be feasible for all small businesses.

Ultimately, the size of a company that offers profit-sharing will depend on the specific circumstances of the business, and there is no specific minimum size requirement for offering this benefit.
what industry is profit sharing offered the most

Profit-sharing is a popular benefit across many industries, but it is more commonly offered in certain industries than others. According to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, industries that are more likely to offer profit-sharing to employees include:

1. Management, scientific, and technical consulting services
2. Securities, commodities, and financial services
3. Information services
4. Manufacturing
5. Wholesale trade

However, it's worth noting that profit-sharing is not limited to these industries and may be offered in other industries as well. The decision to offer profit-sharing is ultimately up to the employer, and may depend on various factors such as company size, profitability, and competition for skilled workers in the industry.
what is an example of a profit sharing software tool

There are several profit-sharing software tools available in the market. One example is "Performio," which is a cloud-based performance management and commission tracking software that can also be used to manage profit-sharing plans. Performio allows companies to set up and automate profit-sharing plans, calculate payouts based on various performance metrics, and generate reports to track the effectiveness of the program. It also offers features such as goal-setting, real-time reporting, and integration with other business systems. Another example is "CaptivateIQ," which is a commission management platform that can be customized to handle different types of incentive compensation programs, including profit-sharing. CaptivateIQ allows companies to set up profit-sharing plans with different tiers, rules, and conditions, and automate the calculation and distribution of payouts. It also offers features such as analytics, forecasting, and collaboration tools to help companies optimize their profit-sharing plans.
what are others

There are several profit-sharing software tools available in the market, each with their unique features and pricing. Some of the other examples of profit-sharing software tools include:

1. Gusto - A cloud-based HR software that offers payroll, benefits, and profit-sharing plans.
2. Shareworks by Morgan Stanley - A cloud-based equity management platform that allows companies to set up and manage profit-sharing plans.
3. ADP - A payroll and HR software that offers a profit-sharing module for companies to set up and manage their plans.
4. Oracle HCM Cloud - A cloud-based HR management software that offers profit-sharing plan tracking, performance metrics, and reporting.
5. Bonusly - A cloud-based employee recognition and rewards software that allows companies to set up profit-sharing programs based on specific employee achievements.
6. HRCloud - A cloud-based HR software that offers profit-sharing plan tracking and employee payout calculation.

These are just a few examples of the profit-sharing software tools available in the market, and companies should evaluate their specific needs and requirements before selecting a software solution.
what is the average revenue

The average revenue of small businesses in the United States can vary widely depending on the industry, location, and other factors. According to the Small Business Administration (SBA), the average revenue for a small business in the United States was $1.2 million in 2020. However, this figure can vary greatly depending on the size and type of business.

For example, small businesses in the healthcare and social assistance industry had an average revenue of $1.7 million, while small businesses in the retail trade industry had an average revenue of $797,000. The average revenue for small businesses in the construction industry was $1.6 million, while the average revenue for small businesses in the professional, scientific, and technical services industry was $1.5 million.

It's worth noting that the definition of a small business varies depending on the industry and other factors such as annual revenue and number of employees. The SBA defines a small business based on industry-specific size standards that take into account factors such as the average annual receipts or the number of employees in the industry.
what is a profitable restaurant group

A profitable restaurant group is a company or organization that owns and operates multiple successful restaurant businesses. These groups may have a variety of restaurant concepts under their umbrella, ranging from fast-casual to fine dining. The profitability of a restaurant group is determined by factors such as revenue, profit margin, customer satisfaction, and employee retention. Some examples of profitable restaurant groups include Darden Restaurants (owners of Olive Garden, LongHorn Steakhouse, and others), Bloomin' Brands (owners of Outback Steakhouse, Carrabba's Italian Grill, and others), and Union Square Hospitality Group (owners of Shake Shack, Gramercy Tavern, and others).
what is a private profitable restaurant group

A private profitable restaurant group is a privately-owned company or organization that operates multiple successful restaurant businesses. Unlike publicly-traded restaurant groups, private restaurant groups are not listed on stock exchanges and do not have shareholders. Instead, they are owned by individuals, families, or private equity firms. Private restaurant groups can be profitable by maintaining a strong focus on customer satisfaction, maintaining efficient operations, and managing costs effectively. Examples of private profitable restaurant groups include Lettuce Entertain You Enterprises, the Batali & Bastianich Hospitality Group, and the Starr Restaurant Group.
who is CEO of lettuce entertain you enterprises
The CEO of Lettuce Entertain You Enterprises is R.J. Melman.
what department would be responsible for buying profit sharing software

The department responsible for buying profit sharing software would likely be the human resources (HR) department. This is because profit sharing is typically a part of employee compensation and benefits, which falls under the purview of HR. However, depending on the size and structure of the company, other departments such as finance, accounting, or operations may also be involved in the decision-making process for purchasing software that affects the company's financial management or reporting.
what is the title of the person

The title of the person responsible for buying profit sharing software may vary depending on the company and its organizational structure. However, it is likely that the decision-maker in the HR department would be either the Chief Human Resources Officer (CHRO), Director of Human Resources, or HR Manager. In smaller companies, it could be the owner or CEO who handles HR responsibilities and makes decisions on software purchases.
